article: Vincent van Gogh was not always an artist. In fact, he wanted to be a(n) church minister and was even sent to the Belgian _ community of Borinage. He discovered that the miners there _ deplorable working conditions and poverty-level wages. Their families _ simply to survive. He felt concerned that the small amount of money he received from the church _ him a moderate life-style, which, in contrast , seemed to him unfair. One cold February evening, while he watched the miners trudging home, he _ an old man staggering toward him across the fields, _ in a burlap sack for warmth. Van Gogh laid his own clothing out on the bed, set aside enough for one change, and decided to give the rest away. He gave the old man a suit of clothes and gave his overcoat to a pregnant woman whose _ had been killed in a cave-in. He lived on starvation rations and spent his money on _ for the miners. When children in one family had fever, though _ himself, he packed up his bed and took it to them. A (an) _ family in the community offered him free room and board. Van Gogh _ the offer, stating that it was the final temptation he must reject if he was to _ serve his community of poor miners. He believed that if he wanted them to _ him, he must become one of them. And if they were to learn of love through him, he must love them enough to _ with them. He was aware of the wide chasm between words and actions. He knew that our lives always _ louder and clearer than words. Others are " _ " carefully to your actions. What are you saying to them?
